poem:
**Alchemy of Tongues**

In a studio,  
ink bleeds—  
cigarette dusk, berry  
whispers, and kohl  
secrets whisper  
against parchment,  
vanishing languages  
revive—  
echoes of Sylheti,  
Tamajaght, kling  
new light  
etched from  
dark brushstrokes,  
birthing lost  
voices in  
a fading world—  
syllables alight  
like smoke  
find form  
  
in alchemist hands.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Do you speak Sylheti? Tamajaght? Klingon? Inside the Festival for Endangered Languages In his studio, Sam Winston appears less artist, more linguistic alchemist. He is experimenting with manufacturing inks out of tobacco from Marlboro cigarettes, the juice of Belarusian chokeberries imported in a 100g packet small enough to make it past customs and a strange brew of kohl eyeliner from the Middle East and galena – the mineral form of lead sulfide – from Wales.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
